title: Best food events around Boston and New England for fall 2025
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: The Big E in West Springfield features diverse food vendors including fried Oreos, cream puffs, and regional specialties like Maine potatoes.
What the Fluff? Festival in Somerville offers Fluff-themed games and eats celebrating Marshmallow Fluff's local invention.
Vermont Wine & Harvest Festival includes a Grand Tasting with over 70 vendors and activities like a wine stroll and soup contest.

title: Emmy nominee Jeff Hiller joins the latest episode of the Love Letters podcast
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Jeff Hiller, Emmy-nominated actor from HBO's 'Somebody Somewhere,' features on the Love Letters podcast.
Hiller discusses a relationship from his 20s and the lessons he learned about love and self-worth.
The episode also explores memorable breakup speeches from films like 'When Harry Met Sally' and 'Notting Hill.'

title: Lynn man charged in kidnapping, murder of older sister
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Joshua Smith, 30, of Lynn pleaded not guilty to charges of kidnapping and murdering his sister, Michelle Knox, 38.
Police were called to a Newhall Street apartment before 1 a.m. Sunday after Smith made threatening statements.
Smith, previously charged with multiple offenses, had pleaded guilty to assault with a dangerous weapon in July.

title: Patriots captain believes defense showed ‘glimpse of dominance’ vs. Raiders
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots captain Harold Landry recorded 2.5 sacks in a 20-13 loss to the Raiders.
New England's defense, including free-agent addition Milton Williams, generated significant pressure but allowed 362 passing yards.
Landry emphasized the need for consistency and improvement after the team's Week 1 defensive performance.

title: David Andrews believes this was most disappointing part of Patriots’ season-opening loss
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots' run game struggled in their 20-13 season-opening loss to the Raiders at Gillette Stadium.
David Andrews criticized the offensive line for failing to support the run game against Las Vegas on Sunday.
New England's ground game produced only 60 yards on 18 attempts, causing reliance on the passing game.

title: Marco Sturm maps out the standard he’s setting for Bruins’ training camp
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Marco Sturm prepares for his first Bruins training camp as head coach, emphasizing intensity, accountability, and new standards.
The Bruins, coming off a 33-39-10 season, aim to improve defense and power play under Sturm's guidance.
Sturm's direct communication style is welcomed by players, contributing to a positive team dynamic for the upcoming season.

title: Worcester girl testifies against man accused of kidnapping her, throwing her off bridge
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Joshua Hubert is on trial for allegedly kidnapping, raping, and attempting to murder a Worcester girl in 2017.
The girl, now 15, testified about surviving by pretending to be dead and swimming to shore after allegedly being thrown off a bridge.
Hubert, a family friend, faces multiple charges and has pleaded not guilty; the trial began with opening statements on Monday.

title: Drake Maye doesn’t think he has ‘too much on his plate’ and more from WEEI interview
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots QB Drake Maye addressed his performance in the season-opening loss on 'WEEI Afternoons,' emphasizing the quarterback's workload.
Maye acknowledged the need to improve on avoiding turnovers, citing the third-quarter interception against the Raiders.
Maye commented on Bill Belichick banning Patriots scouts from UNC practices, calling it "unfortunate" but supportive of his former team.

title: ‘Game 1 is always the hardest’: Patriots veteran shares perspective on Will Campbell’s debut
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots rookie tackle Will Campbell struggled in his debut, contributing to two sacks and committing two false start penalties.
Veteran Morgan Moses emphasized learning from challenging starts, recalling his own difficult first NFL game against Aldon Smith.
Coach Mike Vrabel noted the entire offense requires cohesion and efficiency, stressing improvements are needed beyond just the line.

title: Kayshon Boutte reflects on his forgotten history as an elite prospect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Kayshon Boutte was once projected as a first-round NFL Draft pick before an ankle injury affected his college career.
Boutte, now with the Patriots, drew early comparisons to Stefon Diggs and recently had a strong season opener.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel cited Boutte's professionalism and versatility as keys to his development and success.
